description: From Middle English hors, hos, from Old English hās, *hārs, from Proto-Germanic *haisaz, *haisraz, akin to Old Norse háss (West Norse) and heiss (East Norse) (whence Icelandic hás, Norwegian Nynorsk hås, Norwegian Bokmål hes and Swedish hes).

entries.meaning: Having a dry, harsh tone to the voice, as a result of a sore throat, age, emotion, etc.

verbs.description: hoarse (third-person singular simple present hoarses, present participle hoarsing, simple past and past participle hoarsed)

examples: The 15. 3 mo. 1668 - An act maid in a Towne Meting to provent hoarses and meares from doinge damage, as foloeth. All such hoarses and meares, as comonly kepes about the towne, or in the towne stretes, or comonly doth goe in to the towne neck, […]}}
